verification_notes: This node is a question, not an established proposition. From the provided dependencies, the best supported conclusion is only conditional: torsion-free cases are known to work, 2-torsion introduces orbifold/fixed-point complications, and a positive answer requires additional realization and obstruction-vanishing hypotheses. So there is no unconditional claim here to mark as verified.
suggested_improvement: Recast this as an explicit conditional statement, e.g. if a rational Farrell-Jones realization for Gamma is available and all manifold-upgrade/surgery-orbifold obstructions vanish, then such a closed manifold M exists. Also label clearly whether the general case is open.
missing_assumptions: Definition of 'rationally acyclic universal cover' (which homology groups vanish, with reduced vs unreduced convention).
Precise scope of 'uniform lattice in semi-simple group' and torsion allowed (only 2-torsion or arbitrary finite torsion).
Exact obstruction package assumed to pass from orbifold model to manifold model (dimension/category hypotheses, surgery terms).
Whether any extra constraints on M are required (dimension, orientability, smooth vs topological).

verification_notes: The step is mathematically standard if Gamma is a discrete subgroup of isometries of the symmetric space X=G/K: torsion-free implies the action is free (hence X/Gamma is a manifold), and since X is contractible, the quotient is aspherical. If Gamma has torsion, finite-order elements have fixed points in X, so the quotient is naturally an orbifold. The phrase "not manifold" is slightly too strong without qualification (it is generally not a smooth manifold; in special reflection-type situations one can get manifold-with-boundary behavior).
suggested_improvement: State the needed hypotheses explicitly: "Assume Gamma<Isom(X) is discrete and acts properly discontinuously. If Gamma is torsion-free, X/Gamma is an aspherical manifold. If Gamma has nontrivial torsion, stabilizers are nontrivial finite groups, so X/Gamma is an orbifold (typically with singularities), hence not a manifold in the usual smooth sense."
missing_assumptions: Gamma is discrete (so the action on X is properly discontinuous).
X=G/K is contractible (true for the intended noncompact-type symmetric-space setting).
"Not manifold" should be interpreted as "not a smooth manifold" (or exclude boundary-type exceptions).

verification_notes: The statement is directionally correct but not fully justified as written. A proper cocompact action on the manifold X=G/K supports orbifold/Bredon duality in degree d=dim(X), but that yields (at least) a rational Bredon-PD conclusion. To conclude ordinary rational PD for \Gamma, one must additionally state the bridge from Bredon/orbifold duality to group cohomology (using the FH(Q)/fixed-set hypotheses from p7-s3, and typically a torsion-free or finite-index torsion-free reduction, or an explicit argument that torsion is harmless over Q). Also, orientation/local coefficient issues should be specified.
suggested_improvement: Tighten the step to: 'Because \Gamma acts properly cocompactly on the contractible d-manifold X=G/K with finite isotropy, Bredon (orbifold) cohomology satisfies duality in degree d. Combined with p7-s3 (finite FH(Q) model and fixed-point Euler conditions), this gives rational Bredon-PD of dimension d; if \Gamma is torsion-free (or after passing to a finite-index torsion-free subgroup and transferring back over Q), \Gamma is a rational PD group of formal dimension d.'
missing_assumptions: X=G/K is used as a contractible oriented d-manifold (or orientation character is tracked).
Stabilizers are finite and the action is proper cocompact in the Bredon sense.
Explicit hypothesis connecting Bredon/orbifold duality to ordinary group cohomology over Q (e.g., FH(Q) plus torsion-free/virtual torsion-free transfer).
Clarification whether the conclusion is rational Bredon-PD or ordinary rational PD.

verification_notes: As a Smith-theory statement, this is correct: for a p-group action (here p=2), Smith theory’s fixed-point acyclicity/nonemptiness conclusions are fundamentally mod-p (or p-local) and do not extend to characteristic != p coefficients such as Q. Hence there is no Q-coefficient Smith obstruction forcing fixed points for a free Z/2-action on a rationally acyclic space. Caveat: the phrase "no fixed-point constraint" is too broad if read beyond Smith theory (other tools, e.g. Lefschetz-type arguments under extra hypotheses, can impose constraints).
suggested_improvement: Tighten wording to: "There is no Smith-theoretic obstruction over Q; Smith fixed-point constraints for Z/2-actions are mod-2 phenomena." This avoids overclaiming about non-Smith fixed-point obstructions.
missing_assumptions: Specify the class of spaces where Smith theory is being invoked (e.g., finite-dimensional CW/locally compact settings).
Clarify that "rationally acyclic" means reduced homology with Q-coefficients vanishes (and typically connectedness for H0 behavior).
State explicitly that the conclusion is only about Smith theory, not all fixed-point theorems.

verification_notes: As stated, this is a standard conditional surgery-theoretic implication: once the algebraic data (Gamma realized in FH(Q)) is in place and the manifold-upgrade surgery obstruction is zero, existence of the corresponding closed manifold follows. However, the local context does not explicitly state the theorem/hypotheses that make this implication valid, so it is not fully verified from the provided text alone.
suggested_improvement: Tighten the step by explicitly citing the surgery realization/existence theorem being used and listing its hypotheses (e.g., dimension range, category TOP/PL/DIFF, finiteness/Poincare conditions, normal invariant setup), then conclude existence under those assumptions.
missing_assumptions: Dimension and category assumptions required for surgery to classify/realize manifolds
That Gamma in FH(Q) satisfies all algebraic/Poincare duality conditions needed for realization
That vanishing of the stated obstruction is the final obstruction (no secondary obstructions remain)
Compatibility of the Q-coefficient Smith obstruction discussion with the integral/2-torsion realization framework

verification_notes: The argument is not complete as written. There is a major internal inconsistency: Sections 4 and 7 describe Obligation S as open/fallback-dependent, while Section 6(b) and Section 7(1) claim full closure (existence of a closed manifold) via S-rot-II. The decisive step (integral vanishing of the equivariant surgery obstruction theta from a congruence/trivial-holonomy argument) is asserted but not proved in the provided text. The manifold-construction step also omits required verifications: exact hypotheses of the equivariant surgery theorem used, why the cut-and-cap output has pi1 exactly Gamma, and why the universal cover remains Q-acyclic. There is also an apparent indexing/parity tension (n=7 but obstruction stated in L8(Z[Gamma])) that needs explicit justification.
